items.research_context: B&P Code 5536.1/5802/6735 require licensed professional stamps and signatures on all plan sheets and calculations. Both the architectural designer (C. Sanchez) and structural engineer (J. Gonzalez) must stamp and sign their respective sheets.

items.original_wording:
Sheet A1, Provide utility line connections, water, sewer, gas and electrical. City has standard for sewer line connection. See ADU Sewer Connection Detail @ city link.

2nd Review Comment: show/justify:
• Adequacy of existing waste line due to increase to the number of plumbing fixtures (show the size, justify the size for the new demand).
• Adequacy of the existing water meter and line due to increase to the number of plumbing fixtures (show the size, justify the size for the new demand, and show point of connection)

state_law_finding.requirement: DFU values determine minimum waste line sizing. Typical: toilet=4 DFU, shower=2 DFU, lavatory=1 DFU, kitchen sink=2 DFU, clothes washer=3 DFU. 3-inch drain handles up to 42 DFU; 4-inch handles up to 216 DFU.
state_law_finding.adu_exceptions: New detached ADU may require separate utility connection per Gov. Code 66324(e). Connection fees must be proportionate.

city_finding.notes: City has standard ADU Sewer Connection Detail — corrections letter references it. City research pending for URL.

sheet_observation.current_state: No utility line routing shown. No dashed lines for water, sewer, gas, or electrical. No sewer connection detail. Cover sheet scope mentions 'new water meter' but site plan shows nothing.
sheet_observation.what_to_fix: Add dashed utility lines (water, sewer, gas, electrical) from sources to ADU with sizes labeled. Add sewer connection detail per city standard. Show water meter location and point of connection.

items.research_context: CPC Table 702.1 governs DFU calculations. The 600 sq ft ADU likely adds ~12-15 DFU (toilet=4, shower=2, lavatory=1, kitchen sink=2, clothes washer=3). A 3" drain handles up to 42 DFU, a 4" drain handles up to 216 DFU. The contractor needs to provide existing waste line size and current DFU load to verify capacity. City of Placentia has a standard ADU sewer connection detail that should be referenced.

items.original_wording:
Calculations sheet 3 of 37. Provide calculations and structural details for new covered landing patio. Overhang/cantilever is not detailed in structural plan sheet S1.
a. Provide structural detail and cantilever dimension.

2nd Review Comment: Provide additional information for the braces supporting the beam at the covered landing patio. Show the angle of the brace supporting the beam. Detail the lag screw connection between the brace to beam and brace to post. Show the required posts supporting the braces on the framing plan and list the post size. Provide updated calculations to verify that the covered landing patio is designed for component and cladding wind force per ASCE 7-16 section 30.11.

state_law_finding.requirement: Component and cladding wind pressure calculations required for open/canopy roof structures. Requires basic wind speed, exposure category, effective wind area, and net pressure coefficients.
state_law_finding.adu_exceptions: None — full structural code compliance required per Gov. Code 66314(d)(8)

sheet_observation.current_state: Foundation plan shows 'CONC. LANDING PER ARCH'L' but no structural framing for covered structure above. Framing plan shows only main ADU framing — no post locations, beam sizes, or bracing for patio cover.
sheet_observation.what_to_fix: Structural engineer must add: (1) post locations/sizes on framing plan, (2) beam/header for patio cover, (3) brace angle and lag screw connection detail, (4) cantilever dimension, (5) updated C&C wind calculations per ASCE 7-16 §30.11

items.research_context: ASCE 7-16 §30.11 governs wind loads on open buildings/canopies. Southern California basic wind speed is ~95-110 mph for Risk Category II. The structural engineer must provide: brace angle, lag screw connection details (brace-to-beam and brace-to-post), post sizes on framing plan, and updated component and cladding wind calculations. This is entirely professional work — the contractor may be asked about existing patio conditions to help scope the work.

items.original_wording: Provide the drainage slope and direction around all portions of the ADU (5% at landscape or 2% at hardscape away from the foundation).

city_finding.notes: 5% at landscape / 2% at hardscape away from foundation is standard building code requirement (CRC R401.3). City research pending for any local grading ordinance additions.

sheet_observation.current_state: Sheet A1.1 has no grading info — it's a demolition plan only. No spot elevations, drainage arrows, or slope percentages anywhere in the plan set.
sheet_observation.what_to_fix: Add drainage plan showing slope direction and percentages around all ADU perimeter. Show existing and proposed finish grades.

items.research_context: CRC R401.3 requires minimum drainage slope away from foundation: 5% (6" in 10 feet) at landscape or 2% at hardscape. The contractor needs to provide finished grade elevations at ADU corners so the designer can draw the drainage plan with arrows and slope percentages.

items.research_context: The roof plan shows a gable roof with ridge running roughly east-west. The elevation labels need to match the actual building orientation on the site plan. The designer needs to verify which faces are gable ends vs eave sides and correct the elevation drawings accordingly. This is a drawing coordination issue — no contractor input needed.

items.original_wording: Revise the roof plan to show the low roof covered landing patio. Current roof plan appears to show an extension of the roof rafters and is inconsistent with the elevation views and structural sheets.

sheet_observation.current_state: Roof plan shows main gable roof but does not clearly delineate a separate low-roof structure for the covered landing patio. The patio cover appears to be shown as a continuation of the main roof rafters.
sheet_observation.what_to_fix: Revise roof plan to show: (1) covered landing patio as distinct lower roof element (shed roof or flat), (2) break between main roof and patio roof, (3) appropriate framing indication. Must be consistent with elevations and structural sheets.

items.research_context: Drawing coordination issue between roof plan, elevations, and structural sheets. The covered landing patio must be shown as a separate lower roof structure, not an extension of the main gable rafters. The designer must revise the roof plan to be consistent with what the structural engineer details (Item 5) and what the elevations show.

items.original_wording: Covered landing patio is within 5' of the imaginary property line. 1-hour fire protection is required for the underside of the covered landing patio (CRC R302.1). Please show on the plans and provide a detail. Note, detail 2/A3 does not match the condition at this location and is not valid to address this comment.

state_law_finding.requirement: Within 5' of property line: 1-hour fire-resistance rating required on exterior side of walls, 1-hour fire protection on underside of projections (eaves, soffits, patio covers). No ADU exemption — Gov. Code 66314(d)(12) sprinkler exception does NOT apply to fire separation requirements.
state_law_finding.adu_exceptions: None for CRC R302.1. The 4-foot max rear setback (Gov. Code 66314(d)(7)) frequently places ADUs within the 5-foot fire separation zone.

sheet_observation.current_state: Detail 2/A3 shows a standard (non-fire-rated) wall section. The correction explicitly states this detail does not match the condition and is not valid.
sheet_observation.what_to_fix: Designer must provide a NEW fire-rated assembly detail showing 1-hour fire protection on the underside of the covered landing patio. Typical solution: 5/8" Type X gypsum board on the underside of the patio soffit/roof framing.

items.research_context: CRC R302.1 requires 1-hour fire protection for projections within 5' of property line. The covered landing patio is within this zone. Detail 2/A3 is explicitly rejected by the plan checker. The designer must create a new fire-rated assembly detail — typically 5/8" Type X gypsum board on the underside of the patio soffit framing. This new detail must be specific to the patio cover condition, not a generic wall section.
